metadata.title: Synthesis of secondary amines by reductive alkylation using copper chromite catalyst: Steric effect of carbonyl compounds

Pillai* Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras 600 036 (India) (Received February 25, 1993; accepted May 28, 1993 ) Abstract The steric effect was studied from the synthesis of various aromatic secondary amines by reductive alkylation of aniline with carbonyl compounds over copper chromite. Different aliphatic secondary amines were also prepared by reductive alkylation of methylamine and ethanolamine with carbonyl compounds over copper chromite catalyst. Almost 100% selectivity was observed in all cases. Under optimum conditions of reaction the yield of N-isopropylaniline was 91% and that of N-benzylethanolamine was 94% . The reactivity is decreased with increase in steric hindrance at the carbonyl carbon. Key words: copper chromite; reductive alkylation; secondary amines, steric effects. Introduction Aromatic and aliphatic secondary amines are used as antioxidants in petrochemicals in polymers and in rubber. They are used for the preparation of a variety of dye intermediates and dyes [ 1 ] . N-Alkylated amines are also used in the synthesis of pharmaceutical compounds [ 2 ] . Alkylation of aniline is normally carried out in liquid phase using homogeneous catalysts [ 3-6 ] . Reductive amination of acetone with ammonia on tin modified skeletal nickel catalysts was reported [ 7 ] . The effect of promoters onpt/Si02catalysts for N-alkylation of ortho disubstituted aniline with methoxy-2-propanol in vapour phase was studied [ 8 ] . For the synthesis of tertiary amines by reductive alkylation of aliphatic secondary amines with ketones, palladium, platinum, rhodium and their sulphates were used [ 9 ] . The NN-dimethyl dodecylamine from dodecyl alcohol and dimethylamine was prepared using copper and nickel stearates [ 10 ] . In the present study various secondary amines were prepared by reductive alkylation of primary amine with different carbonyl compounds over copper chromite catalyst. Synthesis of N-alkylatedaniline using copper chromite is proved to be an efficient method [ 11-14 ] . Since the selectivity and activity of the copper chromite catalyst used for the synthesis of secondary *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/93/$06.00 0 1993 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 126 R.B.C. Pillai /J. Mol. Catal. 84 (1993)125-129 amines by reductive alkylation of primary amines with aterically hindered carbonyl compounds was not reported elsewhere in detail, the present study was undertaken. Experimental Barium oxide promoted copper chromite was used as the catalyst [Commercial catalyst, Harshaw Cu-1184T, Composition: Cu0 (44 wt% ), Cr203 (45 wt% ), Ba0 (9 wt% ), BET surface area: 80 m2/g, pore volume: 0.20 cc/g, Copper content: 35%, Chromium content: 31% ]. The catalyst was prereduced by heating in a current of air at 300 C for 4 h, followed by passing hydrogen at the same temperature for 4 h. Preactivation conditions were optimized in our previous studies [ 11 ] . The reactions were carried out in a Teflon lined autoclave of 500 ml capacity. After charging the reactants the autoclave was flushed with nitrogen then with hydrogen. The reactions were performed at 140 C under 50 bar hydrogen pressure with continuous stirring. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The quantitative yield of the products were determined by gas chromatography using a Carbowag column. The secondary amines were characterised by IR, PMR and mass spectra. No other product was detected under the analytical conditions. Since the secondary amine was the only product formed from the primary amine under the experimental conditions, the selectivity is almost 100%. Results and discussion The reductive alkylation of aniline with acetone (1: 3 mole) at 140 C under 50 bar hydrogen pressure for 1 h using fresh copper chromite yielded 70% of N-isopropylaniline. From our earlier studies [ 11 ] it was discovered that the catalyst requires prereduction. The reaction of aniline with acetone using prereduced catalyst gave 91% N-isopropylaniline with almost 100% selectivity. The mechanism of the reductive alkylation is straight forward. The amine condenses with carbonyl compound to give the imine which will get reduced in the presence of hydrogen and catalyst. Though the secondary amine can in principle react further with the ketone to form tertiary amine, this was not observed in any of the reactions studied. Ketone is reduced to secondary alcohol in a parallel reaction. From our earlier studies it was inferred that Cu' 1 state is the active species of the catalyst for the reductive alkylation process. Reductive alkylation of aniline with different carbonyl compounds In continuation of the study of the reaction of acetone with aniline the reactions of several other carbonyl compounds with aniline were performed. Methyl ethyl ketone, methyl isobutyl ketone, benzaldehyde, acetophenone and R.B.C. Pillai /J Mol. Catal. 84 (1993)125-129 127 benzophenone were used for the reductive alkylation of aniline. The reactions proceeded smoothly, and the respective N-alkylanilines were obtained in good yield and selectivity. The main interest in the present study was to compare the different ketones in relation to steric factors. The results of the reaction of acetone, methyl ethyl ketone, and methyl isobutyl ketone with aniline are reported in Table 1. For the latter two ketones, these are not the optimum conditions for best yield, but these conditions were fixed for the purpose of the comparison of reactivity. The reactivity decreased in going from acetone to methyl ethyl ketone to methyl isobutyl ketone. Hence it appears that steric effects are important in the reductive alkylation of aniline by ketones over copper chromite under the present reaction conditions. This conclusion is further confirmed by the data in Table 2 for the reaction of aniline with benzaldehyde, acetophenone and benzophenone, though the variations are not as striking as for the aliphatic ketones. TABLE 1 Comparative study of the formation of secondary alcohol and the formation of secondary amines in various reductive alkylation processes Reaction' Secondary Secondary alcohol' amines' aniline +acetone 82.7 91.0 aniline+MEK 32.2 79.7 aniline+MIBK 28.8 65.8 'Conditions: time=60 (min), T=140 C, P-50 bar, catalyst=4 wt. %, MEK=methyl ethyl ketone, MIBK=methyl isobutyl ketone, aniline: ketone =1:3 (mol). 'Yield (mol%) of secondary amines based on aniline. 'Yield (mol%) of alcohols based on ketones. TABLE 2 Variation of product yield of secondary amines on reductive alkylation of aniline with different aromatic carbonyl compounds Carbonyl Time (h) T ( C) P (bar) Yield' of 2 compound amine benzaldehyde 4 140 50 75.2 acetophenone 4 140 50 70.1 benzophenone 4 140 50 68.3 'Conditions: aniline: carbonyl compound=1:1 (mol), catalyst=4 wt.% (based on total reactants), benzene=100 ml (as solvent). 'Yield (mol%) based on aniline. 128 RA C. Pillai /J. Mol. Catal. 84 (1993)125-129 Reaction of ethanolamine with Onzaldehyde, acetophenone and Onzophenone There is a report [ 15 ] of the reductive amination of a series of ketones by ethanolamine using a platinum oxide catalyst; in addition, in this paper it has been mentioned that nickel and copper chromite can also be used, but details are not given. In the present study the reaction of benzaldehyde and some other carbonyl compounds with ethanolamine was taken up for detailed investigation. Reaction of ethanolamine with benzaldehyde, acetophenone and benzophenone using copper chromite (4%) at 140 C, 50 bar hydrogen pressure, for 60 min was performed. It was observed that under identical reaction conditions, the yield of the corresponding secondary amine decreased (Table 3) . Reductive alkylation of methylamine The reaction between methylamine and acetone, methyl ethyl ketone and methyl isobutyl ketone were also studied. For the study of the reductive alkylation of methylamine with benzaldehyde, acetophenone and benzophenone, with amine: the carbonyl compound ratio was 1:1 (molar ratio). The amine and aromatic carbonyl compound were heated at 140 C, 50 bar hydrogen pres- TABLE 3 Variation of yield of secondary amines on reductive alkylation' of ethanolamine with different carbonyl compounds Carbonyl Time (min) T ( C) P (bar) Yielde of compound amine benzaldehyde 60 140 50 94.0 acetophenone 60 140 50 61.3 benzophenone 60 140 50 53.2 'Solvent: benzene, catalyst=4 wt.%, amine:carbonyl compound=1:1 (mol). 'Yield (mol%) is based on ethanolamine. TABLE 4 Reductive alkylation' of methylamine with carbonyl compounds Experiment Carbonyl Time T P (bar) Yield' of compound (h) ( C) 2 amine 1 benzaldehyde 4 140 50 66.2 2 acetophenone 4 140 50 64.8 3 benzophenone 4 140 50 56.1 4 acetone 2 140 50 64.2 5 methyl ethyl ketone 2 140 50 49.0 6 methyl isobutyl ketone 2 140 50 43.2 'Benzene= 100 ml (solvent), methylamine:carbonyl compound=1:1 (mol) for experiments 13, methylamine:carbonyl compound=1:3 (mol) for experiments 4-6. b Yield (mol%) is based on methylamine. R.B.C. Pillai / J. Mol. Catal. 84 (1993)125-129 129 sure for 4 h in the presence of the prereduced catalyst (3% ). It was observed that the secondary amines were selectively produced under the reaction conditions (Table 4). The carbonyl compounds were reduced to the alcohols in parallel reactions. A comparison of the yields of secondary amines with different carbonyl compounds shows the same trend as with aniline and ethanolamine, the reactivity decreasing with increase in steric hindrance at the carbonyl carbon. Summary Barium promoted copper chromite was shown to be an excellent catalyst for the synthesis of N-alkylated anilines and N-alkylated aliphatic amines because the selectivity was almost 100% ; under the optimum reaction conditions the yield of N-isopropylaniline was 91% and that of N-benzylethanolamines was 94% . By optimizing reaction conditions the yield of other secondary amines can be greatly improved. The yield of secondary amines with different carbonyl compounds proved that the reactivity is decreasing with increase in steric hindrance at carbonyl compounds.
